abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated as satisfactory
            and project sustainability is highly likely. The
            performances of both the World Bank and the Borrower are
            rated satisfactory. The project's successes in housing
            finance are owed to a very large extent to good financial
            and judicial fundamentals, and extreme care taken in
            designing the Jordan Mortgage Refinance Company (JMRC) and
            its lending and borrowing mechanisms to avoid both
            uncertainties in financial contracts and distortions in the
            sector. The legal basis for loans pledged as collateral to
            JMRC had been researched, and framework agreements with
            participating banks made clear. As a result, there was not a
            single instance of a conflict arising between JMRC and a
            bank regarding mortgage-loan collateral. The only main point
            of contention between JMRC and banks has been the pricing of
            JMRC's loans, with banks invariably wanting loans at
            rates too low to support JMRC's costs of funding and
            operations. That problem resulted from a distortion in the
            financial sector that had not been made clear during
            preparation. This leads to a key lesson regarding the
            housing finance component: Deepening financial markets,
            including creating secondary markets for loans and
            increasing institutional investment opportunities, depends
            not only on creating frameworks for new financing
            mechanisms, but also most importantly on the underlying
            market for primary lending and general economic activity.
